p: Rainfall increases the fecal pollution in rivers and freshwater resources, and elevates the bacterial risk [ 70]. Warm temperatures and extreme rainfall are often contributing factors to waterborne disease outbreaks, for example, in Canada [ 71]. Heavy rainfall and floods are associated with extreme weather and may account for 55% and 53% of waterborne outbreaks, respectively [ 23]. Extreme weather events and changes in patterns increase the risk of gastrointestinal diseases. For example, in Japan (1999 to 2007), about 7.7% and 2.3% of infectious gastroenteritis case increases per week were recorded for a 1 Â°C increase in the average temperature and for every 1% decrease in relative humidity, respectively [ 72].
